text: You curse your own men for their ineptitude. You flog them for their weakness, you execute them for their cowardice. The disorganised mob you call an army brings shame to the very name of your people.

The untrustworthy masses under your alleged control mock you with their incompetence. Your chieftains openly plot against each other and bicker over petty disputes, and your warriors care more about securing their gains than riding into battle. Can you risk your grasp on power slipping even further?

You need to bring a heightened sense of order and discipline to your hordes. All they seem to care about is amassing personal glory, and hoarding the spoils of battle. Their greed and avarice may bring about your downfall, lest you cull their baser instincts.

Your armies spread out, seeking glory and victory. Although your weak hearted Han rivals may attempt to sway your mind with treaties and promises, pay them no attention. Only the hunger for battle can keep your hordes loyal and able.

With soaring morale, and rousing chants, your men charge into the most dangerous of frays. The battle cries of your people echo out, and your martial traditions are on full display. Be sure to keep your force as tempered as a good blade, and aim them as true as well shot arrow.
With vim and vigor, your armies are truly relentless. Is there any force in the land capable of halting your momentum?
Your military might decimates all that stand before you! Let rivals try and oppose you. You will crush them, like all the rest.
[[b]] Barbaric Fervour[[/b]] can be raised by being in wars, certain settlement actions.
[[b]] Barbaric Fervour[[/b]] can be lower by not being wars and faction rank.
The people of the Han call you "uncivilised", "primitive" or "barbaric." They consider your people their lessers. Prove them wrong.
The people of the Han call you "uncivilised", "primitive" or "barbaric." They consider your people their lessers. Prove them wrong.
